Entity-semantic_actuator_network.label: Semantic Actuator Network
Entity-semantic_actuator_network.description: The Semantic Actuator Network (SAN) is a core actuation semantic model within the Internet of Things ontology (IoT-O) that facilitates the integration and interoperability of actuators in Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems connected to the Internet.

Entity-context.label: context
Entity-context.description: The 'context' refers to a novel Context Model within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that is designed to describe various real and virtual environments, facilitating context-aware interactions in Brain-Computer Interface applications.

Entity-the_main_contribution.label: the main contribution
Entity-the_main_contribution.description: The main contribution refers to the introduction of the concepts of context and contextual relations in the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), which establishes a first-class semantic model for context-aware BCI applications that interact meaningfully with IoT-based systems.

Entity-bci_application.label: BCI application
Entity-bci_application.description: A BCI application refers to a software or system that utilizes brain-computer interface technology to facilitate direct communication between the brain and external devices, enabling various functionalities such as control of computers or assistive devices.

Entity-sosa_and_san_axiom.label: SOSA and SAN axioms
Entity-sosa_and_san_axiom.description: The SOSA and SAN axioms refer to foundational principles from the Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA) ontology and the Semantic Actuation Network (SAN) ontology, which are integrated within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) to model the relationships and functionalities of actuations and actuators in context-aware Brain-Computer Interface applications.

Entity-bci_context-aware_application.label: BCI context-aware applications
Entity-bci_context-aware_application.description: BCI context-aware applications are software solutions that utilize brain-computer interface technology to adapt and respond to the user's context and interactions with their environment.

Entity-observation__actuation__and_inter.label: observations, actuations, and interactions
Entity-observation__actuation__and_inter.description: The term 'observations, actuations, and interactions' refers to the conceptual components within the Brain-Computer Interface Ontology (BCI-O) that define the bidirectional relationship between a subject and its context, encompassing the collection of contextual input data (observations), the actions taken by the subject (actuations), and the resulting interactions within the environment.

Entity-novel_context_model.label: novel Context Model
Entity-novel_context_model.description: The novel Context Model refers to a component of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that formalizes and integrates context-related metadata for describing various real and virtual environments in the context of Brain-Computer Interface applications.

Entity-context_model.label: Context Model
Entity-context_model.description: The Context Model refers to a novel framework within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that is designed to describe various real and virtual environments, facilitating context-based semantic interoperability in Brain-Computer Interface applications.

Entity-bci_system.label: BCI systems
Entity-bci_system.description: BCI systems refer to brain-computer interface systems that facilitate direct communication between the brain and external devices, enabling control and interaction through neural signals.

Entity-novel_interface.label: novel interfaces
Entity-novel_interface.description: Novel interfaces refer to advanced interaction mechanisms in Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) that enable seamless integration and interoperability with Internet-of-Things (IoT) systems, enhancing human-computer interaction in real-world applications.

Entity-san_concept.label: SAN concepts
Entity-san_concept.description: SAN concepts refer to a set of ontological definitions and axioms related to actuations and actuators within the context of the Internet of Things (IoT), which are integrated into the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) to enhance semantic interoperability in Brain-Computer Interface applications.

Entity-internet_of_brain.label: Internet of Brains
Entity-internet_of_brain.description: The 'Internet of Brains' refers to a conceptual framework where brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) are fully integrated with the Internet of Things (IoT), enabling semantic interoperability and control of real-life objects through BCI technology.

Entity-modeling_integration.label: modeling integration
Entity-modeling_integration.description: Modeling integration refers to the process of aligning and reconciling the BCI-O Context Model with the SOSA and SAN ontologies to enhance the semantic interoperability of actuation events and their effects within Brain-Computer Interface systems.

Entity-bci__context.event.label: bci:Context.Event
Entity-bci__context.event.description: bci:Context.Event refers to a classification within the BCI Ontology that encompasses key concepts related to the integration of context in Brain-Computer Interface systems, specifically including bci:StimulusEvent, bci:Action, and bci:ActuationEvent.

Entity-meaningful_interaction.label: meaningful interactions
Entity-meaningful_interaction.description: Meaningful interactions refer to the effective and context-aware communication and engagement between Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) applications and Internet-of-Things (IoT) systems, facilitated by a semantic model that enhances interoperability and responsiveness in real-time environments.

Entity-san.label: SAN
Entity-san.description: SAN refers to the Semantic Sensor Network Ontology, which provides axioms for actuations and actuators within the context of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) framework for Brain-Computer Interaction and Internet of Things integration.

Entity-contextual_notion.label: contextual notions
Entity-contextual_notion.description: The term 'contextual notions' refers to the conceptual frameworks and principles that underpin the integration of context-aware elements within the BCI-O's Actuation Model, facilitating interoperability and semantic understanding in Brain-Computer Interface applications connected to the Internet of Things.

Entity-san__iot-o_.label: SAN (IoT-O)
Entity-san__iot-o_.description: SAN (IoT-O) refers to a standard framework that integrates contextual notions for modeling actuations and actuators within the Internet of Things, specifically designed to enhance semantic interoperability in Brain-Computer Interface applications.

Entity-this_scenario.label: this scenario
Entity-this_scenario.description: This scenario refers to a specific use case in which a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system is utilized to control a wheelchair based on processed EEG signals from a user, illustrating the integration of BCI-O's Actuation Model with IoT devices to achieve context-aware actuation.

Entity-core_model.label: core models
Entity-core_model.description: The term 'core models' refers to the fundamental conceptual components defined in the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that facilitate the interaction between subjects and contexts in Brain-Computer Interface systems, specifically including the Sense Model and Actuation Model.

Entity-bci_session.label: BCI session
Entity-bci_session.description: A BCI session refers to an interactive process involving brain-computer interface technology, where signals from the brain are used to control external devices or receive feedback, typically involving sensors and actuators.

Entity-specific_concept_aligned_to_the_s.label: Specific concepts aligned to the SOSA/SSN axioms
aliases: Specific concepts aligned to the SOSA/SSN axioms
Entity-specific_concept_aligned_to_the_s.description: Specific concepts aligned to the SOSA/SSN axioms refer to the defined elements and structures used in the BCI-O ontology to model observations within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction, ensuring semantic interoperability and accurate representation of sensory data and events.

mentions.local_name: Specific concepts aligned to the SOSA/SSN axioms

Entity-the_context.label: the context
Entity-the_context.description: In this paper, 'the context' refers to the specific environmental and situational factors that influence and are influenced by the interactions between a subject and actuators in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system, as modeled in the BCI Ontology's Actuation Model.

Entity-bci__activity.label: bci:Activity
Entity-bci__activity.description: bci:Activity refers to a specific task or action performed by a bci:Subject within the context of a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) session, which is integral to the interaction model that connects observations and actuations in a given environment.

Entity-bidirectional_subject-context_int.label: bidirectional subject-context interaction model
Entity-bidirectional_subject-context_int.description: The bidirectional subject-context interaction model is a theoretical framework within the BCI-O ontology that describes the interaction between a subject and its context during a BCI session, comprising a Sense Model that captures context-to-subject interactions and an Actuation Model that facilitates subject-to-context interactions.

Entity-core_module.label: core modules
Entity-core_module.description: The term 'core modules' refers to the fundamental conceptual components of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that facilitate the interaction between subjects and contexts in Brain-Computer Interface systems, specifically focusing on the Actuation Model and its integration with contextual elements.

Entity-bci__actuation.label: bci:Actuation
Entity-bci__actuation.description: bci:Actuation refers to the process or action within the Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) framework that represents the interaction and effect of a subject's actions on the surrounding context during a BCI session.

Entity-iot-o.label: IoT-O
Entity-iot-o.description: IoT-O refers to a set of axioms that integrate the Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA) framework with the Semantic Web standards for the Internet of Things, facilitating context-aware actuation in Brain-Computer Interface systems.

Entity-real-world_activity.label: real-world activities
Entity-real-world_activity.description: Real-world activities refer to practical, everyday tasks and interactions that individuals engage in, which can be enhanced or facilitated by Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) technologies and their integration with Internet of Things (IoT) systems.

Entity-core_pre-requisite.label: core pre-requisite
Entity-core_pre-requisite.description: The term 'core pre-requisite' refers to the essential requirement of context-based semantic interoperability that is necessary for the effective functioning of context-aware Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) actuation applications in real-time collaborative Internet of Things (IoT) environments.

Entity-bci_domain.label: BCI domain
Entity-bci_domain.description: The BCI domain refers to a conceptual area within Brain-Computer Interaction that encompasses observations, actuations, and interactions between a subject and their context.

Entity-sensor__observation__sample__and_.label: Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator
Entity-sensor__observation__sample__and_.description: The mention 'Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator' refers to the SOSA upper ontology, which provides a framework for describing sensor-actuator systems and their interactions in the context of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) for real-world applications.

Entity-use_case_(1).label: use case
Entity-use_case_(1).description: A use case in this context refers to a specific scenario that illustrates the application of the BCI-O Actuation Model, demonstrating how a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) can control an actuator, such as a wheelchair, based on brain signal inputs from an EEG sensor.

Entity-bci__aspect.label: bci:Aspect
Entity-bci__aspect.description: bci:Aspect refers to the specific characteristics or features associated with the modalities of observations in the context of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems, which are integral to the integration of sensory data and actuations.

Entity-bci_community.label: BCI communities
Entity-bci_community.description: BCI communities refer to groups and networks of researchers, developers, and practitioners focused on the development and application of Brain-Computer Interface technologies, particularly in the context of integrating these systems with Internet of Things (IoT) frameworks.

Entity-san__iot-o__axiom.label: SAN (IoT-O) axioms
Entity-san__iot-o__axiom.description: SAN (IoT-O) axioms refer to a set of formal principles and standards that guide the modeling of actuations and actuators within the context of the Internet of Things, specifically integrated into the BCI Ontology's Actuation Model.

Entity-integrated_concept.label: integrated concepts
Entity-integrated_concept.description: Integrated concepts refer to the theoretical frameworks and models that align with the SOSA and SAN (IoT-O) axioms, specifically designed for the representation and interaction of actuations and actuators within the context of Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) and Internet of Things (IoT) systems.

Entity-internet-of-things-__iot__-based_.label: Internet-of-Things- (IoT)-based systems
Entity-internet-of-things-__iot__-based_.description: Internet-of-Things (IoT)-based systems refer to interconnected networks of devices and sensors that communicate and exchange data over the Internet, enabling automation and enhanced interaction in various applications, including those in the context of Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI).

Entity-san_alignment.label: SAN Alignments
Entity-san_alignment.description: SAN Alignments refer to the integration and reconciliation of SAN axioms within the BCI-O framework, specifically for modeling actuations and actuators in the context of Brain-Computer Interfaces and Internet of Things applications.

Entity-modeling_consideration.label: modeling considerations
Entity-modeling_consideration.description: Modeling considerations refer to the integration and refinement of ontological concepts from the SOSA and SAN frameworks in the context of actuations and actuators within the BCI-O ontology, aimed at enhancing semantic interoperability and context-awareness in Brain-Computer Interface applications.

Entity-bci__actuationevent.label: bci:ActuationEvent
Entity-bci__actuationevent.description: bci:ActuationEvent refers to an effect or change of state in the bci:Context that results from a bci:Actuation, as defined within the BCI-O framework for modeling interactions in Brain-Computer Interfaces.

Entity-bci__modality.label: bci:Modality
Entity-bci__modality.description: bci:Modality refers to the various types of modalities that characterize the different forms of observations and inputs in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system, which are essential for the interaction between the subject and the context.

Entity-contextual_component.label: contextual components
Entity-contextual_component.description: The term 'contextual components' refers to the elements within the BCI-O's Actuation Model that represent the various aspects of the environment and situation that a subject interacts with while using actuators in Brain-Computer Interface applications.

Entity-human-computer_interaction__hci_.label: human-computer interaction (HCI)
Entity-human-computer_interaction__hci_.description: Human-computer interaction (HCI) refers to the interdisciplinary field focused on the design and use of computer technology, emphasizing the interfaces through which humans interact with computers, particularly in the context of Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) that facilitate intuitive and natural interactions in real-world activities.

Entity-the_relationship_from_and_to_actu.label: The relationships from and to actuation and other concepts
aliases: The relationships from and to actuation and other concepts
Entity-the_relationship_from_and_to_actu.description: The relationships from and to actuation and other concepts refer to the defined connections and interactions between the actuation process and various related concepts within the BCI Ontology, particularly as they pertain to the integration of SOSA and SAN axioms in modeling actuations and their effects in context-aware systems.

mentions.local_name: The relationships from and to actuation and other concepts

Entity-modeled_concept.label: modeled concepts
Entity-modeled_concept.description: The term 'modeled concepts' refers to the specific theoretical and conceptual elements defined within the BCI-O Actuation Model that describe the interactions and relationships between brain-computer interface inputs, actuators, and the contextual environment in which they operate.

Entity-sosa__actuator.label: sosa:Actuator
Entity-sosa__actuator.description: sosa:Actuator refers to a device that implements an actuation, transforming an input signal into a physical output, thereby changing the state of a context in systems such as Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) and the Internet of Things (IoT).

Entity-contextual_concept.label: contextual concepts
Entity-contextual_concept.description: The term 'contextual concepts' refers to the theoretical framework and understanding that integrates contextual information into the BCI-O's Actuation Model, enabling semantic interoperability and context-aware applications in Brain-Computer Interface and Internet of Things environments.

Entity-ontological_notion.label: ontological notions
Entity-ontological_notion.description: Ontological notions refer to the abstract concepts and relationships that define the nature of entities and their interactions within a specific domain, particularly in the context of modeling actuation events and their effects in Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems integrated with Internet of Things (IoT) frameworks.

Entity-bci__context.object.label: bci:Context.Object
Entity-bci__context.object.description: bci:Context.Object refers to an entity that represents a specific object involved in the contextual interactions within a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) session.

Entity-subject-context_personalization.label: subject-context personalization
Entity-subject-context_personalization.description: Subject-context personalization refers to the tailored interaction and adaptation of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems based on the specific needs and contexts of individual users, enhancing their experience and effectiveness in controlling actuators within their environment.

Entity-it_conceptual_component.label: Its conceptual components
Entity-it_conceptual_component.description: The term 'Its conceptual components' refers to the elements within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that define the structural, functional, and temporal complexities of environments in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) and its integration with actuators and sensors.

Entity-the_environment.label: the environment
Entity-the_environment.description: The environment refers to the real or virtual settings in which subjects interact with actuators in Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) applications, influencing how these interactions are modeled for personalized context-aware functionalities.

Entity-bci__context.scene.label: bci:Context.Scene
Entity-bci__context.scene.description: bci:Context.Scene refers to a specific indoor situation within the context of a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) application, where the interaction between the user and the environment is modeled for actuations.

Entity-context_domain.label: context domain
Entity-context_domain.description: The 'context domain' refers to the conceptual area that encompasses the surroundings and environmental factors relevant to the interactions and operations within a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system.

Entity-sosassn_definition.label: SOSA/SSN definitions
Entity-sosassn_definition.description: SOSA/SSN definitions refer to the formalized ontological concepts and axioms from the Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA) and Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) ontologies, which are integrated into the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) to model actuations and actuators in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction and Internet of Things applications.

Entity-the_contextual_interaction_of_the.label: the contextual interaction of the bci:Session
aliases: the contextual interaction of the bci:Session
Entity-the_contextual_interaction_of_the.description: The contextual interaction of the bci:Session refers to the dynamic relationship and engagement of objects within a specific session of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI), where these objects are influenced by and contribute to the context of the interaction.

mentions.local_name: the contextual interaction of the bci:Session

Entity-the_conclusion.label: the conclusions
Entity-the_conclusion.description: The conclusions refer to the final section of the paper that summarizes the main contributions and findings related to the BCI Ontology's Actuation Model and its implications for context-aware BCI applications in IoT environments.

Entity-_2_.description: The term [2] refers to a specific reference in the context of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that defines the relationships between actuation and other related concepts, serving as a foundational element for understanding the integration of actuations and their effects within the model.

Entity-bci__stimulusevent.label: bci:StimulusEvent
Entity-bci__stimulusevent.description: bci:StimulusEvent refers to a specific type of event within the BCI Ontology that serves as a stimulus to the bci:Subject, facilitating interaction in a context-aware Brain-Computer Interface system.

Entity-surroundings.label: surroundings
Entity-surroundings.description: In the context of the BCI-O framework, 'surroundings' refers to the context domain that encompasses the physical or virtual environment in which the Brain-Computer Interface operates, facilitating the interaction between the subject and the contextual elements.

Entity-it_description_and_source_code.label: its description and source code
Entity-it_description_and_source_code.description: The term 'its description and source code' refers to the publicly accessible documentation and implementation code for the BCI-O Actuation Model, which outlines the integration of Brain-Computer Interface concepts with actuator systems in IoT environments.

Entity-concept.label: concepts
Entity-concept.description: In the context of the BCI-O framework, 'concepts' refers to the specific theoretical constructs and ideas that are defined and aligned with the SOSA/SSN axioms for modeling observations within Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-another_inherited_modeling_perspe.label: Another inherited modeling perspective for BCI
aliases: Another inherited modeling perspective for BCI
Entity-another_inherited_modeling_perspe.description: Another inherited modeling perspective for BCI refers to the integration of the san:impacts object property within the BCI Ontology, which establishes a relationship between the effects of actuations and the properties they impact, thereby enhancing the semantic modeling of actuation events in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

mentions.local_name: Another inherited modeling perspective for BCI

Entity-any_kind_of_physical_modification.label: any kind of physical modification
Entity-any_kind_of_physical_modification.description: The term 'any kind of physical modification' refers to the changes or effects on the physical world that result from the actions of an actuator in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) context, specifically as defined within the framework of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) and its integration with the Internet of Things (IoT).

Entity-bci__actuator.label: bci:Actuator
Entity-bci__actuator.description: bci:Actuator refers to a device that implements an actuation to change the state of a context, functioning as a component within the BCI Ontology that aligns with the definitions of sosa:Actuator and san:Actuator.

Entity-san__actuatorinput.label: san:ActuatorInput
Entity-san__actuatorinput.description: san:ActuatorInput refers to a specific type of input signal or command that is utilized by an actuator to perform an actuation in the context of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems.

Entity-relation.label: relation
Entity-relation.description: In the context of the BCI-O Actuation Model, 'relation' refers to the connections or links between actuation events, actuators, and impacted properties, which are essential for modeling the interactions and effects within a context-aware system.

Entity-bci__channelingspec.label: bci:ChannelingSpec
Entity-bci__channelingspec.description: bci:ChannelingSpec refers to a specification within the BCI Ontology that defines the parameters and characteristics for channeling data from observations to actuators in a Brain-Computer Interface system.

Entity-modeling_observation.label: modeling observations
Entity-modeling_observation.description: Modeling observations refers to the process of defining and structuring contextual input data and events related to a subject in Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems, utilizing specific concepts aligned with the SOSA/SSN axioms to facilitate the integration of multimodal records and sensor outputs.

Entity-dul.label: DUL
Entity-dul.description: DUL refers to the Dolce-Ultralite ontology, which is utilized in the BCI-O framework to ensure semantic precision and consistency in the modeling of actuation concepts and their relationships within the context of Brain-Computer Interfaces.

Entity-interaction.label: interactions
Entity-interaction.description: In the context of the BCI-O framework, 'interactions' refer to the dynamic exchanges between a BCI subject and its surrounding context, encompassing both observations and actuations within a bidirectional interaction model.

Entity-module.label: modules
Entity-module.description: In the context of the BCI-O framework, 'modules' refer to the core conceptual components that define the interaction between subjects and contexts in Brain-Computer Interface systems, specifically focusing on aspects related to actuations, sessions, and observations.

Entity-state_of_the_context.label: state of the context
Entity-state_of_the_context.description: The 'state of the context' refers to the condition or status of the environment that is modified through the actuation process in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system, facilitated by an actuator.

Entity-subject.label: subject
Entity-subject.description: In the context of the paper, 'subject' refers to the user or participant in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) session who interacts with the system and its environment through observations and actuations.

Entity-bci__subject.label: bci:Subject
Entity-bci__subject.description: The bci:Subject refers to an entity that interacts with a bci:Context during a BCI session, performing a specific activity within the framework of Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-actuation_(1).label: Actuation
Entity-actuation_(1).description: Actuation refers to the procedures that change the state of devices, such as controlling the movement of a wheelchair, through the implementation of commands derived from brain signals in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) context.

Entity-iot_and_bci_community.label: IoT and BCI communities
Entity-iot_and_bci_community.description: The IoT and BCI communities refer to the collective groups of researchers, practitioners, and enthusiasts focused on the Internet of Things (IoT) and Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) technologies, exploring their integration and applications.

Entity-contextual_input_data.label: contextual input data
aliases: the contextual input data and events to the subject
Entity-contextual_input_data.description: The term 'contextual input data' refers to the observations and events that provide relevant information about the environment and stimuli to the subject in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system.

mentions.local_name: the contextual input data and events to the subject

Entity-degree.label: degree
Entity-degree.description: The term 'degree' in this context refers to the level of significance or importance that the BCI-O's Actuation Model will have in achieving context-based semantic interoperability for BCI applications within IoT environments.

Entity-core_model_for_the_iot_ontology__.label: core model for the IoT Ontology (IoT-O)
aliases: core model for the IoT Ontology (IoT-O)
Entity-core_model_for_the_iot_ontology__.description: The core model for the IoT Ontology (IoT-O) refers to a foundational framework that integrates and reconciles various axioms related to actuations and actuators, facilitating semantic interoperability within Internet of Things (IoT) systems.

mentions.local_name: core model for the IoT Ontology (IoT-O)

Entity-environment.label: environment
Entity-environment.description: In this context, 'environment' refers to the architectural description of any physical or virtual setting that encompasses the structural, functional, and temporal complexities relevant to Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) interactions.

Entity-sosa.label: SOSA
Entity-sosa.description: SOSA refers to the Semantic Sensor Network Ontology, which provides a framework for integrating sensor data and actuation models within the context of Brain-Computer Interfaces and Internet of Things applications.

Entity-san__actuation.label: san:Actuation
Entity-san__actuation.description: san:Actuation refers to a formalized concept within the BCI Ontology that describes the process of changing the state of a context through the use of an actuator, integrating principles from the SOSA and SAN ontologies.

Entity-purpose.label: purpose
Entity-purpose.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), 'purpose' refers to the fundamental objectives and goals that guide the design and implementation of the BCI-O framework, particularly in relation to its core models and applications.

Entity-bci__context.method.label: bci:Context.Method
Entity-bci__context.method.description: bci:Context.Method refers to the specific actuation procedure of decelerating a wheel in the context of controlling a wheelchair using brain-computer interface inputs.

Entity-an_actuation.label: an actuation
Entity-an_actuation.description: An actuation refers to a procedure carried out by an actuator that changes the state of a context within a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system, impacting specific properties of an actuation target.

Entity-bci__recordeddata.label: bci:RecordedData
Entity-bci__recordeddata.description: bci:RecordedData refers to the sensor output data that serves as an input to an actuator within the context of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems.

Entity-instruction.label: instruction
Entity-instruction.description: In the context of Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI), 'instruction' refers to a specific command or signal that directs an actuator to execute a function, thereby initiating an actuation process.

Entity-bci__session.label: bci:Session
Entity-bci__session.description: bci:Session refers to a data structure that encapsulates the interaction between a bci:Subject and a bci:Context while executing a single bci:Activity, organizing both observations and actuations within the BCI-O framework.

Entity-procedure.label: procedure
Entity-procedure.description: The term 'procedure' refers to a systematic method or process employed to change the state of a context through the use of an actuator in the context of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems.

Entity-brain-computer_interface.label: Brain-Computer Interfaces
Entity-brain-computer_interface.description: Brain-Computer Interfaces are systems that facilitate direct communication between the brain and external devices, enabling users to control technology through neural activity.

Entity-san__impact_object_property__san_.label: san:impacts object property: san:Effect
Entity-san__impact_object_property__san_.description: The entity 'san:impacts object property: san:Effect' refers to a relationship in the BCI Ontology that defines how an effect, induced by an actuator, impacts a property of an actuation target within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction and Internet of Things integration.

Entity-an_actuator_(1).label: an actuator
Entity-an_actuator_(1).description: An actuator is a device that implements an actuation to change the state of a context, transforming an input signal into a physical output, and is integral to the operation of sensor-actuator systems in Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) and Internet of Things (IoT) environments.

Entity-sosa__actuation.label: sosa:Actuation
Entity-sosa__actuation.description: sosa:Actuation refers to a conceptual model within the SOSA ontology that represents the process of carrying out a procedure to change the state of a context using an actuator, integral to the integration of sensor-actuator systems in applications such as Brain-Computer Interfaces.

Entity-observation_component.label: observation component
Entity-observation_component.description: The observation component refers to the elements in the BCI-O framework that are responsible for collecting and processing brain signal data, specifically the EEG recordings and the EEG device used to capture these signals, which serve as inputs for actuations in a Brain-Computer Interface application.

Entity-domain_level_concept.label: domain level concepts
Entity-domain_level_concept.description: Domain level concepts refer to the high-level abstractions and frameworks that are specifically designed to model and integrate context-aware functionalities within the BCI-O ontology, aligning with SOSA and SAN axioms for effective actuation and actuator representation.

Entity-core_abstraction.label: Core Abstractions
Entity-core_abstraction.description: Core Abstractions refers to a fundamental model within the BCI-O framework that outlines the procedures and relationships involved in actuating changes in a context through the use of actuators.

Entity-a_procedure_to_change_the_state_o.label: a procedure to change the state of the context
aliases: a procedure to change the state of the context
Entity-a_procedure_to_change_the_state_o.description: The term 'a procedure to change the state of the context' refers to an actuation process that utilizes an actuator to modify the properties or conditions of a specific context within a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) framework.

mentions.local_name: a procedure to change the state of the context

Entity-bci__command.label: bci:Command
Entity-bci__command.description: bci:Command refers to a specific order or instruction given to an actuator to perform an actuation, serving as the input that triggers the actuator's basic functions.

Entity-fig.5.label: Fig.5
Entity-fig.5.description: Fig.5 illustrates the modeled concepts involved in a use case where a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) controls a wheelchair based on EEG signals, detailing the relationships between the subject, session, activity, context, and actuation commands.

Entity-bci__impactedproperty_-__is_prope.label: bci:ImpactedProperty - (is property of) -> sosa:FeatureOfInterest
Entity-bci__impactedproperty_-__is_prope.description: The entity 'bci:ImpactedProperty' refers to a specific quality or characteristic of an actuation target, which is represented as 'sosa:FeatureOfInterest' in the context of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems, indicating the property that is affected by an actuation event.

Entity-standard_axiomatization_model_for.label: standard axiomatization models for actuations
Entity-standard_axiomatization_model_for.description: Standard axiomatization models for actuations refer to formal frameworks developed by the W3C/OGC and IoT communities that provide structured definitions and relationships for actuations within the context of sensor-actuator systems, particularly in the integration of Brain-Computer Interfaces and Internet of Things applications.

Entity-bci__record.label: bci:Record
Entity-bci__record.description: bci:Record refers to a multimodal observation that serves as an input to an actuator within the context of a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) session.

Entity-event.label: events
Entity-event.description: In the context of the BCI-O framework, 'events' refer to specific occurrences that provide contextual input data to the subject, including stimulus events, actions performed by the subject, and actuation events that result from the subject's interactions within a given context.

Entity-observation.label: observations
Entity-observation.description: In the context of the BCI-O framework, 'observations' refer to the multimodal records of contextual input data and events that inform the subject's interaction with the environment during a BCI session.

Entity-effect.label: effect
Entity-effect.description: In the context of Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI), the term 'effect' refers to any physical modification that is induced by an actuator as a result of an actuation event.

Entity-the_modeled_concept.label: the modeled concepts
Entity-the_modeled_concept.description: The modeled concepts refer to the specific entities and relationships defined within the BCI-O Actuation Model that describe the interactions between a subject, their EEG recordings, the actuators controlling a wheelchair, and the contextual elements of the environment in which these interactions occur.

Entity-alice.label: Alice
Entity-alice.description: Alice is an individual who is using a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) to control a wheelchair through EEG signals in a context-aware application.

Entity-conceptual_component.label: conceptual components
Entity-conceptual_component.description: The term 'conceptual components' refers to the elements within the BCI-O framework that define the structural, functional, and temporal complexities of environments in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-two_distinct_conceptual_domain.label: Two distinct conceptual domains
Entity-two_distinct_conceptual_domain.description: The term 'Two distinct conceptual domains' refers to the BCI domain, which encompasses observations, actuations, and interactions, and the context domain, which represents the surrounding environment, as defined in the interaction model of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O).

Entity-dul_alignment_module.label: DUL alignment module
Entity-dul_alignment_module.description: The DUL alignment module refers to a framework that integrates the Dolce-Ultralite ontology with the BCI-O's Context Model to enhance the semantic precision of concepts related to actuation and its effects in Brain-Computer Interface systems.

Entity-scenario.label: scenario
Entity-scenario.description: The term 'scenario' refers to a specific use case in the context of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) applications, illustrating how various components interact to control a wheelchair based on EEG signals from a subject.

Entity-public_access.label: public access
Entity-public_access.description: Public access refers to the availability and accessibility of the BCI-O framework and its components to users and developers, enabling interaction and integration with Brain-Computer Interface systems.

Entity-fig_._1.label: Fig. 1
Entity-fig_._1.description: Fig. 1 is a visual representation that illustrates the conceptual components of a bidirectional subject-context interaction model in brain-computer interfaces (BCIs).

Entity-her_wheelchair.label: her wheelchair
Entity-her_wheelchair.description: Her wheelchair refers to a mobility device that is controlled autonomously through a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) by interpreting the user's neurophysiological signals.

Entity-the_following_relationship_(1).label: the following relationships
Entity-the_following_relationship_(1).description: The term 'the following relationships' refers to the specific ontological connections and definitions that describe how various concepts related to actuation, such as san:Effect, bci:ImpactedProperty, and their interactions, are structured and aligned within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) framework.

Entity-bci__action.label: bci:Action
Entity-bci__action.description: bci:Action refers to an action issued by a bci:Subject while performing a bci:Activity within the context of the BCI-O framework.

Entity-controlling_the_automated_wheelch.label: controlling the automated wheelchair
Entity-controlling_the_automated_wheelch.description: Controlling the automated wheelchair refers to the process of using brain-computer interface (BCI) technology to direct the movement and actions of a wheelchair based on brain signals interpreted from an EEG sensor.

Entity-user_s_brain_state.label: user's brain states
Entity-user_s_brain_state.description: The term 'user's brain states' refers to the neurophysiological signals collected and analyzed by Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) to determine the mental and emotional conditions of a user, which are characterized by their situational variability, individual dependence, and non-stationary nature.

Entity-any_environment.label: any environment
Entity-any_environment.description: The term 'any environment' refers to the comprehensive architectural description of both physical and virtual settings that encompasses their structural, functional, and temporal complexities within the context of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems.

Entity-bcieeg.label: BCI/EEG
Entity-bcieeg.description: BCI/EEG refers to technologies that facilitate communication between the brain and external devices, utilizing electroencephalography to measure electrical activity in the brain for applications such as controlling assistive devices.

Entity-user.label: user
Entity-user.description: The term 'user' refers to an individual whose brain states are analyzed by Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) to actuate specific responses, such as controlling a wheelchair autonomously.

Entity-the_device_that_perform_the_actua.label: the devices that perform the actuations
aliases: the devices that perform the actuations
Entity-the_device_that_perform_the_actua.description: The devices that perform the actuations refer to actuators that implement procedures to control physical systems, such as a wheelchair, based on input from brain-computer interface (BCI) signals.

mentions.local_name: the devices that perform the actuations

Entity-bci__actuationtarget.label: bci:ActuationTarget
Entity-bci__actuationtarget.description: bci:ActuationTarget refers to the specific components of a wheelchair, namely the two rear wheels, that are controlled by actuators based on commands derived from brain signals in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system.

Entity-real_life_object.label: real life objects
Entity-real_life_object.description: Real life objects refer to tangible, physical entities in the real world that can be modeled, controlled, and interacted with through Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCIs) connected to the Internet.

Entity-reduce_the_speed_of_wheel.label: reduce the speed of wheels
Entity-reduce_the_speed_of_wheel.description: The phrase 'reduce the speed of wheels' refers to the actuation event in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system where an actuator decreases the rotational speed of a wheelchair's wheels based on processed brain signals from the user.

Entity-capability_of_an_actuation.label: capability of an actuation
Entity-capability_of_an_actuation.description: The 'capability of an actuation' refers to the inherent potential of an actuation to influence or modify a specific quality or property of an actuation target, as defined within the context of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) and its integration with the SOSA and SAN frameworks.

Entity-specific_response.label: specific responses
Entity-specific_response.description: Specific responses refer to the actions or outputs generated by Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) in reaction to analyzed neurophysiological signals, such as autonomously driving a wheelchair.

Entity-parameter.label: parameters
Entity-parameter.description: In the context of the BCI-O Actuation Model, 'parameters' refer to specific values associated with commands issued to actuators, such as 'direction' and 'acceleration', which dictate the behavior of the actuator in response to brain signals.

Entity-modeling_depiction.label: modeling depiction
Entity-modeling_depiction.description: The term 'modeling depiction' refers to the conceptual representation that illustrates the composition of three key concepts related to the actuation target within the BCI-O framework, integrating elements from the SOSA and SAN ontologies.

Entity-happening.label: happening
Entity-happening.description: In the context of Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI), 'happening' refers to an event that impacts a quality or property, specifically a type of actuatable property that can be modified by an actuation, thereby representing a change in the physical world triggered by an actuator.

Entity-san__actuatoroutput.label: san:ActuatorOutput
Entity-san__actuatoroutput.description: san:ActuatorOutput refers to the concept within the BCI Ontology that represents the output or effect produced by an actuator as a result of an actuation event, which modifies a property of the physical world.

Entity-inferred_relationship.label: inferred relationship
Entity-inferred_relationship.description: The term 'inferred relationship' refers to the semantic connections that can be deduced between concepts within the BCI-O framework, particularly how actuation events impact properties of actuation targets as defined by the alignments to the SAN ontology.

Entity-sosa__actuatableproperty.label: sosa:ActuatableProperty
Entity-sosa__actuatableproperty.description: sosa:ActuatableProperty refers to a property or characteristic of an actuation target that can be modified or impacted by an actuator during an actuation event, as defined within the context of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) and its integration with SOSA and IoT-O.

Entity-iot_ontology.label: IoT ontology
Entity-iot_ontology.description: The IoT ontology is a formal representation of concepts and relationships within the Internet of Things domain, designed to facilitate interoperability and data sharing among IoT devices and applications.

Entity-san__effect_definition.label: san:Effect definition
Entity-san__effect_definition.description: The term 'san:Effect definition' refers to the ontological concept that describes the physical modifications induced by an actuator in the context of Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI), specifically detailing how an actuation event impacts a quality or property of an actuation target.

Entity-a_set_of_bci__record.label: a set of bci:Record
Entity-a_set_of_bci__record.description: A set of bci:Record refers to a collection of structured data entries that serve as input commands for actuators in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system, facilitating the execution of specific actions based on the defined commands.

Entity-this_concept.label: this concept
Entity-this_concept.description: This concept refers to a context event that is triggered by an actuator and results in a change to the impacted property of the actuation target within the framework of the BCI Ontology.

Entity-three_concept.label: three concepts
Entity-three_concept.description: The 'three concepts' refer to the foundational elements that compose the Actuation Target in the BCI-O model, specifically including a sosa:FeatureOfInterest, a relationship from a sosa:Actuation, and a bci:Context.Object.

Entity-composite.label: composite
Entity-composite.description: In the context of the BCI-O Actuation Model, 'composite' refers to the wheelchair as a complex object that integrates multiple components and functionalities, enabling it to respond to commands derived from brain signals.

Entity-physical_output.label: physical output
Entity-physical_output.description: The term 'physical output' refers to the tangible result produced by actuators in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system, which is generated as a response to an input signal and represents a modification in the physical world.

Entity-axiomatization_model.label: axiomatization models
Entity-axiomatization_model.description: Axiomatization models refer to standardized frameworks developed by W3C/OGC and IoT communities that provide formal structures for defining and integrating actuations within the context of the BCI-O's Actuation Model.

Entity-the_thing__actuation_target_.label: the thing (actuation target)
Entity-the_thing__actuation_target_.description: The thing (actuation target) refers to an entity whose properties are manipulated by an actuator within a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) context, serving as a feature of interest in the actuation process.

Entity-hci.label: HCI
Entity-hci.description: HCI refers to the interdisciplinary field of human-computer interaction, which studies the design and use of computer technology, focusing particularly on the interfaces between people (users) and computers.

Entity-human_interface.label: human interface
Entity-human_interface.description: The term 'human interface' refers to a system composed of an EEG sensor, a computing system for processing brain signals, and an actuator that collectively enable a user to control a wheelchair through brain-computer interaction.

Entity-dul__event.label: dul:Event
Entity-dul__event.description: dul:Event refers to an event triggered by an actuator that modifies the physical world, specifically categorized as a type of bci:Context.Event within the context of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems.

Entity-transition.label: transition
Entity-transition.description: In the context of the BCI-O Actuation Model, 'transition' refers to the change from one state to another in an actuation event, specifically indicating a modification of an impacted property as a result of an actuation effect triggered by an actuator.

Entity-bci__executes.label: bci:executes
Entity-bci__executes.description: bci:executes refers to the relationship where a BCI actuator performs a specific command, triggering an actuation process.

Entity-axiomatization_satisfiability.label: axiomatization satisfiability
Entity-axiomatization_satisfiability.description: Axiomatization satisfiability refers to the degree to which the axioms defined within a theoretical framework, such as the BCI-O's integration with SOSA and SAN, can be satisfied or fulfilled in the context of modeling actuations and actuators.

Entity-the_internet.label: the Internet
Entity-the_internet.description: The Internet refers to the global network of interconnected computers and devices that communicate using standardized protocols, enabling the exchange of data and services across various applications, including those in Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems.

Entity-the_following_relationship.label: the following relationship
Entity-the_following_relationship.description: The following relationship refers to the connections and interactions defined in the context of the Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE) ontology design pattern, specifically how various concepts such as actuation, effect, and impacted property are interrelated within the BCI-O framework.

Entity-aae_odp.label: AAE ODP
Entity-aae_odp.description: AAE ODP refers to the Actuation-Actuator-Effect Ontology Design Pattern, which serves as a core model for integrating and reconciling actuation concepts within the Internet of Things Ontology (IoT-O) framework.

Entity-w3c_semantic_sensor_network.label: W3C Semantic Sensor Network
Entity-w3c_semantic_sensor_network.description: The W3C Semantic Sensor Network is a standard that provides an ontology for describing sensors, observations, and related concepts to facilitate interoperability and data integration in sensor networks.

Entity-an_effect_on_the_physical_world.label: an effect on the physical world
aliases: an effect on the physical world
Entity-an_effect_on_the_physical_world.description: An effect on the physical world refers to any physical modification or change in state that results from an actuation event triggered by an actuator within the context of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems.

mentions.local_name: an effect on the physical world

Entity-relationship.label: relationships
Entity-relationship.description: The term 'relationships' refers to the connections and associations defined between actuation and other related concepts within the context of the BCI-O Actuation Model.

Entity-bci__actuationresult.label: bci:ActuationResult
Entity-bci__actuationresult.description: bci:ActuationResult refers to an entity that represents the effect of an actuation, specifically the outcome associated with an actuation event, and is aligned with the concepts of sosa:Result and san:ActuationValue.

Entity-physicalvirtual_environment.label: physical/virtual environment
Entity-physicalvirtual_environment.description: The term 'physical/virtual environment' refers to the architectural framework that encompasses both tangible and digital settings in which interactions occur, as defined within the BCI-O's context model.

Entity-specific_indoors_situation.label: specific indoors situation
Entity-specific_indoors_situation.description: The term 'specific indoors situation' refers to a defined context within a home environment where a subject, Alice, interacts with a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system to control a wheelchair, highlighting the unique conditions and elements present during the actuation process.

Entity-subject_s_head.label: subject's head
Entity-subject_s_head.description: The term 'subject's head' refers to the anatomical location from which brain signals are recorded using an EEG sensor in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system.

Entity-wheel.label: wheels
Entity-wheel.description: In the context of a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system, 'wheels' refers to the mechanical components of a wheelchair that are controlled by an actuator to change the wheelchair's movement state, such as deceleration.

Entity-spec_s_human-readable_version.label: spec's human-readable version
Entity-spec_s_human-readable_version.description: The 'spec's human-readable version' refers to an accessible and comprehensible documentation of the BCI-O Actuation Model, including its description and source code, intended for users to understand and implement the model in practical applications.

Entity-actuation-actuator-effect__aae_.label: Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE)
Entity-actuation-actuator-effect__aae_.description: The Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE) refers to an ontology design pattern that serves as a foundational model for integrating actuations, actuators, and their effects within the context of the Internet of Things (IoT) ontology.

Entity-dolce-ultralite.label: Dolce-Ultralite
Entity-dolce-ultralite.description: Dolce-Ultralite (DUL) refers to an ontological framework that provides a formal structure for representing and integrating concepts related to quality, events, and properties in the context of semantic interoperability, particularly in the domain of Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) and Internet of Things (IoT) applications.

Entity-description.label: description
Entity-description.description: The term 'description' refers to the detailed explanation of the BCI-O actuation concepts and their implementation, which is available in the specification's human-readable version.

Entity-context_event.label: context event
Entity-context_event.description: The term 'context event' refers to an event triggered by an actuator that results in a change to the impacted property of an actuation target within the framework of the BCI-O's Context Model.

Entity-one_of_it_basic_function.label: one of its basic functions
Entity-one_of_it_basic_function.description: The term 'one of its basic functions' refers to the fundamental operations that an actuator performs in response to a command, which triggers an actuation in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system.

Entity-trigger.label: triggers
Entity-trigger.description: In the context of the BCI-O Actuation Model, 'triggers' refers to the relationship where an actuator initiates an actuation event that results in a specific effect on the physical world.

Entity-dul__method.label: dul:Method
Entity-dul__method.description: dul:Method refers to a conceptual representation of a specific procedure or technique that is utilized to instruct an actuator to perform an actuation within the context of the BCI Ontology.

Entity-to_decelerate_it_wheel.label: to decelerate its wheels
Entity-to_decelerate_it_wheel.description: The term 'to decelerate its wheels' refers to the action performed by an actuator in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system that reduces the speed of a wheelchair's wheels based on processed brain signal inputs.

Entity-mapping_of_sosassn_to_aae_odp.label: mapping of SOSA/SSN to AAE ODP
aliases: mapping of SOSA/SSN to AAE ODP
Entity-mapping_of_sosassn_to_aae_odp.description: The mapping of SOSA/SSN to AAE ODP refers to the process of aligning the structural elements of the Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA) and Sensor Network (SSN) ontologies with the Abstract Architecture for the Open Data Platform (AAE ODP) to enhance semantic interoperability in context-aware Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) applications.

mentions.local_name: mapping of SOSA/SSN to AAE ODP

Entity-source.label: source
Entity-source.description: In the context of the paper, 'source' refers to the origin of a set of bci:Record that provides input for actuators in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system.

Entity-actuatable_quality.label: actuatable quality
Entity-actuatable_quality.description: The term 'actuatable quality' refers to a property or characteristic of an actuation target that can be modified or influenced by an actuator in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) context.

Entity-_impact_.label: (impacts)
Entity-_impact_.description: In the context of the BCI-O Actuation Model, 'impacts' refers to the relationship where an effect induced by an actuator modifies or changes a specific quality or property of an actuation target, represented as an 'impacted property'.

Entity-bci__command__x1_.label: bci:Command (x1)
Entity-bci__command__x1_.description: bci:Command (x1) refers to a specific command, such as 'slow down', that is generated from EEG recordings and serves as input for actuators to control the movement of a wheelchair in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system.

Entity-san__actuationvalue.label: san:ActuationValue
Entity-san__actuationvalue.description: san:ActuationValue refers to a data structure that represents the result or effect of an actuation within the context of the BCI Ontology, specifically aligned with the concepts of sosa:Result and bci:ActuationResult.

Entity-bci__impactedproperty.label: bci:ImpactedProperty
Entity-bci__impactedproperty.description: bci:ImpactedProperty refers to an actuatable quality or characteristic of an actuation target that is modified as a result of an actuation event triggered by an actuator, and is aligned with the concept of sosa:ActuatableProperty.

Entity-iot_ontology__iot-o_.label: IoT Ontology (IoT-O)
Entity-iot_ontology__iot-o_.description: The IoT Ontology (IoT-O) is a theoretical framework that provides a structured representation of concepts and relationships within the Internet of Things domain.

Entity-specific_movement_command.label: specific movement commands
Entity-specific_movement_command.description: Specific movement commands refer to the instructions derived from processed brain signals in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system that dictate the actions of an actuator, such as controlling the direction and acceleration of a wheelchair.

Entity-sensor__observation__sample__and_.label: Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA)
Entity-sensor__observation__sample__and_.description: Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA) is an ontology framework that provides a standardized way to describe and integrate sensor data, observations, and actuators in various applications.

Entity-device.label: devices
Entity-device.description: The term 'devices' refers to the actuators that perform the actuation procedures to control the movement of a wheelchair based on input from a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system.

Entity-upper_ontology.label: upper ontologies
Entity-upper_ontology.description: Upper ontologies are high-level frameworks that provide a common vocabulary and structure for integrating and aligning domain-specific ontologies, such as the W3C Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) and Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA), to facilitate semantic interoperability across various applications.

Entity-origin.label: origins
Entity-origin.description: The term 'origins' in this context refers to the foundational aspects and historical development of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), which encompasses its purpose, core models, and overall framework.

Entity-multimodal_record.label: multimodal records
Entity-multimodal_record.description: Multimodal records refer to the diverse types of observational data collected during a BCI session, which are categorized as bci:Record and serve as input for actuators within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-iot_environment.label: IoT environments
Entity-iot_environment.description: IoT environments refer to interconnected settings where devices and systems communicate and exchange data over the Internet, enabling automation and smart functionalities.

Entity-bci__eegrecord.label: bci:EegRecord
Entity-bci__eegrecord.description: bci:EegRecord refers to an EEG observation that serves as the input for actuations in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system, specifically used to control devices like a wheelchair based on brain signal data.

Entity-global_overview.label: global overview
Entity-global_overview.description: The term 'global overview' refers to a comprehensive summary of the origins, purpose, core models, public access, design principles, and applications of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O).

Entity-movement_command.label: movement commands
Entity-movement_command.description: Movement commands refer to specific directives generated from processed brain signals in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system, which instruct actuators on how to control devices such as a wheelchair.

Entity-the_following_premise.label: the following premises
Entity-the_following_premise.description: The term 'the following premises' refers to the foundational assumptions or principles that underpin the development of the BCI-O Actuation Model, specifically aimed at integrating and reconciling the axioms of SOSA and SAN for effective modeling of actuations and actuators.

Entity-procedure_that_change_the_state_o.label: procedures that change the state of the wheels
aliases: procedures that change the state of the wheels
procedures that change the state of the wheels via actuators
Entity-procedure_that_change_the_state_o.description: Procedures that change the state of the wheels refer to the actuation processes implemented by devices that control the movement of a wheelchair based on input from a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI), specifically affecting the speed and direction of the wheels.

mentions.local_name: procedures that change the state of the wheels
procedures that change the state of the wheels via actuators

Entity-ssn.label: SSN
Entity-ssn.description: SSN refers to the W3C Semantic Sensor Network ontology, which provides a framework for modeling sensor networks and their interactions in the context of the Internet of Things.

Entity-actuationresult.label: ActuationResult
Entity-actuationresult.description: ActuationResult refers to the outcome of the actuation process in a BCI system, specifically the effect of decelerating the wheels of a wheelchair based on commands derived from EEG signals.

Entity-direction.label: direction
Entity-direction.description: In the context of the BCI-O Actuation Model, 'direction' refers to a specific movement parameter that indicates the intended path or orientation of the wheelchair as controlled by the actuator based on processed EEG signals.

Entity-bcieeg_record.label: BCI/EEG record
Entity-bcieeg_record.description: A BCI/EEG record is a collection of data obtained from electroencephalography (EEG) that captures brain activity, typically used in brain-computer interface (BCI) applications to interpret neural signals.

Entity-their_state.label: their state
Entity-their_state.description: The mention 'their state' refers to the speed of the wheelchair's wheels as affected by the actuation process in the context of a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system.

Entity-semantic_sensor_network__ssn_.label: Semantic Sensor Network (SSN)
Entity-semantic_sensor_network__ssn_.description: The Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) is an ontology and framework designed to facilitate the integration and interoperability of sensor data and services in the context of the Semantic Web.

Entity-the_actuation_event.label: the actuation event
Entity-the_actuation_event.description: The actuation event refers to a specific occurrence triggered by an actuator that results in a modification of the physical world, specifically changing the state of an actuation target, and is classified as a type of context event within the BCI Ontology.

Entity-san__effect.label: san:Effect
Entity-san__effect.description: san:Effect refers to the concept of a physical modification induced by an actuator, representing the outcome of an actuation event that impacts a quality or property in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction and Internet of Things applications.

Entity-actuator__input_from_the_eeg_reco.label: actuators' input from the EEG record
aliases: actuators' input from the EEG record
Entity-actuator__input_from_the_eeg_reco.description: The term 'actuators' input from the EEG record' refers to the processed brain signals obtained from an EEG recording that serve as commands for actuators to control the movement of devices, such as a wheelchair, in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system.

mentions.local_name: actuators' input from the EEG record

Entity-a_specific_source.label: a specific source
Entity-a_specific_source.description: In the context of the paper, 'a specific source' refers to a defined origin of input data, specifically a set of bci:Record, that provides commands to actuators within the Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system.

Entity-fig_._4.label: Fig. 4
Entity-fig_._4.description: Fig. 4 illustrates the conceptual components that define the structural, functional, and temporal complexities of any physical or virtual environment within the BCI-O framework.

Entity-observed_and_processed_brain_sign.label: observed and processed brain signals
Entity-observed_and_processed_brain_sign.description: Observed and processed brain signals refer to the analyzed electrical activity recorded from the brain via EEG sensors, which are interpreted to generate specific movement commands for actuators in Brain-Computer Interface applications.

Entity-a_type_of_bci__context.event.label: a type of bci:Context.Event
Entity-a_type_of_bci__context.event.description: A type of bci:Context.Event refers to an actuation event that is triggered by an actuator and results in a modification of the physical world, specifically changing the state of an actuation target.

Entity-the_procedure__actuation_.label: the procedure (actuation)
Entity-the_procedure__actuation_.description: The procedure (actuation) refers to the series of steps executed by an actuator to change the state of a device, such as controlling the movement of a wheelchair based on processed brain signals from a BCI system.

Entity-iot.label: IoT
Entity-iot.description: IoT, or the Internet of Things, refers to a network of interconnected devices and systems that communicate and exchange data over the internet, enabling automation and enhanced functionality across various applications.

Entity-w3c_semantic_sensor_network__ssn_.label: W3C Semantic Sensor Network (SSN)
Entity-w3c_semantic_sensor_network__ssn_.description: The W3C Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) is a standard and ontology developed by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) for modeling and representing sensor networks and their observations in a semantic web context.

Entity-sensor-actuator_system.label: sensor-actuator system
Entity-sensor-actuator_system.description: A sensor-actuator system is a technological framework that combines sensors to detect changes in the environment and actuators to perform actions based on the sensor data, enabling automated responses and interactions within various applications.

Entity-the_following_definition.label: the following definition
Entity-the_following_definition.description: The term 'the following definition' refers to a specific ontological definition that is foundational to the Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE) ontology design pattern, which is utilized in the context of modeling actuations and actuators within the BCI-O framework.

Entity-the_physical_world.label: the physical world
Entity-the_physical_world.description: The physical world refers to the tangible environment and entities that can be affected or modified by actions, particularly in the context of actuators and actuation events as described in the BCI Ontology.

Entity-acceleration.label: acceleration
Entity-acceleration.description: In the context of a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system, 'acceleration' refers to the parameter that quantifies the change in speed of the wheelchair's movement, specifically indicating how quickly the wheelchair can increase or decrease its velocity based on commands derived from EEG recordings.

Entity-human-computer_interaction.label: human-computer interaction
Entity-human-computer_interaction.description: Human-computer interaction is a multidisciplinary field of study focused on the design, evaluation, and implementation of interactive computing systems for human use, and the study of the phenomena surrounding them.

Entity-context-aware.label: context-aware
Entity-context-aware.description: Context-aware refers to the capability of a system or application to recognize and respond to the contextual information surrounding it, enhancing user interactions and functionality.

Entity-to_change_the_wheelchair_s_state.label: to change the wheelchair's state
Entity-to_change_the_wheelchair_s_state.description: The term 'to change the wheelchair's state' refers to the actuation process executed by a device that alters the operational condition of the wheelchair, such as adjusting its speed or direction based on input from a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI).

Entity-quality.label: quality
Entity-quality.description: In the context of the BCI-O Actuation Model, 'quality' refers to an actuatable property or characteristic of an actuation target that can be modified by an actuator.

Entity-an_actuator_(2).label: an actuator
Entity-an_actuator_(2).description: An actuator is a device that implements procedures to control the movement of a wheelchair based on processed brain signals from a BCI/EEG system, enabling the wheelchair to respond to specific commands such as acceleration and direction changes.

Entity-oldssn__property.label: oldssn:Property
Entity-oldssn__property.description: oldssn:Property refers to a property that can be impacted by an actuation event, as defined within the context of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) and its alignment with the SAN ontology.

Entity-slow_down.label: slow down
Entity-slow_down.description: The 'slow down' command refers to an instruction issued by a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system to an actuator controlling a wheelchair, indicating a decrease in speed by a specified acceleration value.

Entity-iot-based_system.label: IoT-based systems
Entity-iot-based_system.description: IoT-based systems refer to interconnected devices and technologies that utilize the Internet of Things to collect, exchange, and analyze data, enabling automation and remote control across various applications.

Entity-slowing_down.label: slowing down
Entity-slowing_down.description: The term 'slowing down' refers to the effect of decelerating the wheels of a wheelchair as a result of commands issued from a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system, specifically indicating a reduction in speed.

Entity-an_impacted_property.label: an impacted property
Entity-an_impacted_property.description: An impacted property refers to a specific quality or characteristic of an actuation target that is modified as a result of an actuation event triggered by an actuator in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) context.

Entity-property.label: property
Entity-property.description: In the context of the BCI-O Actuation Model, 'property' refers to an impacted quality or characteristic of an actuation target that is modified as a result of an actuation event triggered by an actuator.

Entity-composition_of_three_concept.label: composition of three concepts
